author: Editor
title: Barbecue smackdown: Which region reigns supreme?
text:
Posted on July 2, 2015 by Editor 
Barbecue is hot, and as its popularity has boomed; the number of restaurants specializing in the cuisine has exploded from coast to coast. From Brooklyn, N.Y. to Portland, Ore. chefs are busy manning their smokers, usually replicating one of the nation’s four major types of barbecue, throwing their allegiance to Memphis, Texas, Kansas City or Carolina-style ‘cue. 
But the ultimate way to experience these regional styles is by tasting each destination — only then can barbecue fans truly pledge loyalty to one place. Below, the true expert breaks down the basics of each barbecue mecca. Share which you insist is worth a pilgrimage on twitter or facebook , so we can name one king — or kingdom. 
THE CAROLINAS 
Packing several distinct styles and specialties into a relatively small region, barbecue in the Carolinas is as varied as the geography. In North Carolina the traditional specialty has long been “whole hog” barbecue. In both states the bestseller is some form of pulled pork. South Carolina has its own significant specialty, a rich, golden hued, mustard-based sauce, and Lexington, N.C. lays claim to red cole slaw, which uses ketchup instead of mayo. The Carolinas’ significant contribution to the conclusion of a great barbecue meal is banana pudding. Read more . 
Last Slide Next Slide 
KANSAS CITY 
An authentic Kansas City dish is burnt ends, and it is exactly what the name implies — burnt ends of a brisket, chopped up and slathered with sauce. A world epicenter of excellent slow smoked barbecue, KC has two homegrown local chains of immense repute, Gates and the even more famous Arthur Bryant’s. Kansas City is on every barbecue fan’s list and for traditional old-school KC, Gates is the place. Read more . 
Last Slide Next Slide 
MEMPHIS 
No city in the country, not Austin, not Houston, not even Kansas City, has as many stand out barbecue eateries as Memphis, with smoked meat everywhere you turn. Memphis also has the greatest variety. The city is most famous for ribs, mainly thanks to the runaway success of Corky’s. Even so, traditionally, the pulled pork sandwich has been the king of Memphis barbecue. Read more . 
Last Slide Next Slide 
TEXAS 
Of all the major regional styles of barbecue in America, Texas BBQ is the most clear cut and delineated, because it always starts with beef, largely in the form of brisket. The other telltale sign that you are at a Texas BBQ joint is the prevalence of European style sausages. There is good barbecue across the Lone Star state, but nowhere is the concentration greater – or better – than in and around Austin, a.k.a. “The Texas Barbecue Belt.”
